I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The country partnership strategy, 2012–2015 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
Viet Nam1 aims to support the reform of state-owned enterprises (SOEs). Reforming SOEs is 
central to its strategy for business development and private-sector-led employment growth. ADB 
has been engaged with Viet Nam’s SOE reform since the late 1990s. The ADB strategy in this 
regard has two defining characteristics: long-term support and responsiveness. The most recent 
ADB country assistance program evaluation recommends ongoing support for SOE reform by 
strengthening institutional capacity and developing ways to interact with public finance reforms.2  
 
2.  The Government of Viet Nam requested ADB to provide technical assistance (TA) to 
support institutional strengthening and capacity development within the Ministry of Finance 
(MOF)  and  in  selected  SOEs  and  thereby  sustain  the  government's  overall  SOE  reform 
agenda.3  An understanding with government counterparts was reached on the objective, scope, 
cost, and implementation arrangements for the TA during the review missions fielded from 25 
February to 1 March 2013 and 2 to 9 May 2013. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Critical to economic growth and protracted nature of reforms. The SOE sector, 
which includes state-owned commercial banks, is critical to Viet Nam’s economic growth. SOEs 
account for over a third of gross domestic product and roughly half of total exports, and are a 
major source of employment. Despite the progress achieved through the Government of Viet 
Nam’s  efforts since 1992, the process of reforming the SOEs has been relatively slow, confined 
mainly to smaller enterprises, and largely focused on equitization (i.e., the process of converting 
SOEs into joint stock companies with limited liability) and mergers and/or divestures of small- 
and medium-sized SOEs. While this has resulted in a marked reduction in the number of SOEs, 
for  the  remaining  SOEs—many  of them  large  in  size,  complex  in  operation,  and  weak  in 
performance—reform has neither had any clear impacts on the reallocation of state resources 
nor created any big change in the state’s role in a market economy. Large general corporations 
(or conglomerates) have mostly converted into holding companies or, in a few cases, economic 
groups have only recently begun the transformation process. Reform and restructuring of large 
SOEs is crucial to reducing the dominance of inefficient state production, promoting private 
sector development, and supporting economic growth.  
 
4.  Key constraints. Key constraints on SOE reform are the large size of corporations in 
general, difficulties in asset valuation, financial constraints, high dependence on government 
support, weak corporate governance, and an inadequate framework for resolving nonperforming 
debts and disposing of related assets. Due to the large scale and complexity of operations,   
management in many general corporations has limitations in terms of skills and capacity to 
undertake the strategic and operational restructuring needed.  Most of the general corporations 
have ventured outside their core business lines and have relied on extensive borrowing from the 
government and state-owned commercial banks to finance their operations, as they have limited 
access to capital markets.  As a result, most of the general corporations have very highly 
leveraged outstanding debt. Under changing economic conditions, this has severely constrained

their ability to service their debts and has contributed to the high level of nonperforming loans in 
the banking system. The problem is exacerbated as much of the debts are short term, and are 
often refinanced  and  rolled  over  with  high  costs. The  valuation  of  general  corporations  is 
complicated  by  the  need  to  value  their  shareholdings  in  several  subsidiaries  that may  be 
engaged in a wide spectrum of businesses. Further, valuation of landholdings and old assets 
without original supporting documents has also proved difficult. 
 
5.  Strategic relevance. The government clearly recognizes the necessity as well as the 
complexity of these reforms, and has adopted a step-by-step approach in line with Viet Nam’s 
Socio-Economic  Development  Strategy,  2011–2015;  the  government  considers  economic 
restructuring—particularly of the finance sector, public investment, and SOEs—as key to long-
term development. To support this effort, the Prime Minister has approved the equitization plans 
of 17 economic groups, and line ministries have approved around 50 restructuring plans of 
general corporations (given that these restructuring plans are mostly developed by the SOEs 
themselves, there may be scope for improvement). The challenge now is how to implement 
them.  The  Prime  Minister’s  decision  of  19  February  2013  (339/QDD-TTg)  envisaged  that 
restructuring SOEs is one of three main foci of overall economic restructuring, besides banking 
sector restructuring and public spending restructuring, to transform the economy and improve its 
competitiveness for the period 2013–2020.  
 
6.  Multitranche financing facility. In December 2009, the Multitranche Financing Facility 
(MFF)  to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  State-Owned  Enterprise  Reform  and 
Corporate Governance Facilitation Program was approved.4 The MFF supports the corporate, 
operational, and financial restructuring of selected individual SOEs on a pilot basis, with a view 
to developing a general approach for SOEs other than state-owned commercial banks to guide 
the reform and restructuring of the remaining large SOEs. The first tranche of the MFF, or 
periodic  financing  request  (PFR)  1,  supports  the  restructuring  and  reform  of  two  selected 
SOEs—Song  Da  Corporation  (SDC),  a  large  construction  conglomerate,  and  Southern 
Waterborne  Transport  Corporation  (SOWATCO),  an  inland  water  transport  and  logistics 
company—based on their readiness to undertake proper corporate, financial, and operational 
restructuring. The MFF is now proposed to be extended to  other qualified SOEs in coordination 
with MOF under the project’s second tranche, or PFR2. This second tranche of $320 million (i.e., 
$310 million from ordinary capital resources [OCR] and $10 million from the Asian Development 
Fund) has been programmed for 2014. The pilot approach is expected to successfully transform 
the selected SOEs and thereby strengthen the government’s resolve to push ahead with further 
SOE restructuring. The proposed model will go beyond mere equitization to comprehensive 
transformation. Demonstration projects under the MFF are expected to provide the model for 
the SOE to reform and restructure. 
 
7.  Progress of facility implementation. There has been good progress in developing the 
corporate and financial restructuring plans for both SDC and SOWATCO, and implementation is 
expected to continue into 2014. SDC has established a steering committee under the chairman 
to implement the restructuring plan. At SOWATCO, a monitoring committee will report progress 
                                                
4  ADB. 2009. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Multitranche 
Financing Facility to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the State-Owned Enterprise Reform and Corporate 
Governance Facilitation Program. Manila. The MFF—with a total allocation of $630 million ($600 million from 
ordinary capital resources OCR and $30 million from the Asian Development Fund)—has been structured into a 
three-tranche program. The first tranche (PFR1) for $130 million ($120 million OCR and $10 million  Asian 
Development Fund) became effective in 2011 and is being implemented. The OCR loan is meant to support the 
financial restructuring of the selected SOEs, while the Asian Development Fund  loan is to help them implement 
the corporate and organizational restructuring, including strengthening corporate governance standards.

3 
to the shareholders. Progress at SDC has been challenging.5 Following the dissolution of the 
economic group, the board members are united in their resolve to implement its restructuring 
plan. However, given the size of the company, heavy debt burden, and the complexity of its 
operations—with multiple lines of business that have made large investments in the last several 
years with limited prospects of returns in the current economic environment—drastic measures 
will need to be taken for its turnaround.  SOWATCO has made good progress given its smaller 
size, and its restructuring plan is being implemented with a focus on two core business lines 
(transport and logistics) and on having a holding company structure that will provide strategy 
and support services.  At a macro level, progress to date on implementing PFR1 has led to new 
policy decisions by the government on how general corporations should be restructured within a 
prescribed  timeline  for  divestment  of  noncore  business  lines.  Under  an  ADB  capacity 
development TA,6 the progress on implementing PFR1 is being tracked, and a monitoring 
framework for the overall MFF is being devised. MOF has plans to make the appointment of 
independent directors to the SOE board mandatory as well as have an independent audit 
committee reporting to the board. 
 
8.  SOE reform is an inherently complex process, requiring holistic financial and corporate 
restructuring. First, this is a novel approach for Viet Nam, formulated with the help of the ADB 
MFF project. Such expertise is not available within SOEs and MOF, and  it takes external 
support to carry out the due diligence process and in the process strengthening if required, of 
already developed restructuring plans. Second, MOF has developed (in consultation with ADB) 
a set of criteria for shortlisting selected SOEs for restructuring support under the MFF's PFR2 
and PFR3, which will enable MOF to assess and rank candidates with the highest potential to 
meet the reform objective.7 Selection criteria were discussed by MOF in a workshop with all 
relevant  stakeholders  and  disseminated  through  the  MOF  website.  Selected  SOEs  will  be 
considered for participation in the second phase of the project and will undergo rigorous due 
diligence by the MOF team, given that the loan is guaranteed by the government. ADB is 
committed to supporting capacity development of MOF, and in turn of the SOEs, in this process. 
Third,  PFR1  implementation  has  underscored  the  need  for  sustained  technical  support  to 
participating SOEs, and also the lack of required technical capacity at MOF. MOF has been 
assigned by the government to take the lead in the development and implementation of an SOE 
restructuring program, which takes into account and builds on lessons and experience gained 
from the implementation of the pilot restructurings under the MFF. In view of this, the proposed 
TA will help MOF in strengthening the institutional process and the policy framework to sustain 
SOE reforms, and help it in preparing candidate SOEs to implement their individual restructuring 
plans, as each is different and unique from the other with regard to its mandate and business 
lines. Such support is not envisaged for PFR3, as MOF's capacity is expected to have been 
strengthened adequately by then. Hence, MOF needs sustained TA support to enable it to 
implement the MFF and to upscale the reform process to all SOEs in the future. In addition to 
the above support, MOF has also requested support for development of knowledge products as 
well as a framework for overseeing the progress of SOE reforms in Viet Nam.  
 
                                                
5 Three years were lost in the case of SDC due to a government decision in January 2010 to convert SDC into an 
economic group by merging five large additional SOEs with SDC. Realizing that this was unwieldy, the government 
reversed the merger in October 2012, thus restoring SDC's original structure. A revised restructuring plan is now 
developed and under implementation.

7 To aid this process, MOF and ADB, supported by external expert advice under the ongoing capacity development 
TA, devised two sets of criteria—six essential criteria and 20 variables. The list is available on request.

4 
 
9.  The implementation of the TA will be informed by lessons and experience of SOE 
reforms undertaken since 1992 and, in particular, the experience from the pilot phase of the 
MFF. Institutional capacity building, extended support during implementation, awareness and 
knowledge of the sociopolitical environment, sensitivities, and ownership of the project are some 
of the key lessons for implementing SOE reforms in the capacity-constrained environment of 
Viet Nam.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The expected impact of the TA overall will be greater profitability of restructured SOEs 
and better management of state-managed investments. The expected outcome will be stronger 
capacity of MOF to facilitate selected SOEs’ transformation into financially viable and efficiently 
managed enterprises.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.   The TA will support MOF in (i) conducting due diligence of selected SOEs,  (ii) finalizing 
the restructuring and implementation plans of selected SOEs, and (iii) developing knowledge 
products to guide SOE reform in Viet Nam. Restructuring plans developed by candidate SOEs 
will be further improved and refined with the support of external experts under the proposed TA 
to ready these additional SOE candidates for participation under PFR2. This is in line with the 
approach adopted and recommended under the ADB MFF project, which aims to strengthen the 
performance of SOEs through holistic restructuring, both corporate and financial. Restructuring 
will  focus  on  core  business  lines;  divestment  of  noncore  business;  financial  restructuring 
through debt restructuring and cost reduction; and organizational restructuring including change 
management, risk management measures, and improvement of information technology and 
staff skills. The restructuring plans so developed for additional SOEs will be screened and 
refined with the support of the TA. In addition, the TA will support institutional strengthening and 
capacity development of MOF in initiating, adopting, and implementing measures in core areas 
of SOE reforms, as it is the leading agency for SOE reform in Viet Nam.  
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of remuneration of counterpart staff, office accommodation, and 
other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  MOF is the executing agency for the MFF overall, and the selected SOEs are the 
implementing agencies for each tranche. For this TA, MOF will be the executing agency and the 
selected  SOEs  will  be  the  implementing  agencies.  A  project  management  unit  has  been 
established within MOF to coordinate activities and monitor the progress of implementation, and 
submit progress reports to ADB. Each selected SOE will establish a unit to oversee project 
implementation  and  provide  progress  reports  to  the  MOF  project  management  unit. 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA implementation period 
will be from 1 August 2013 to 31 December 2014.

5 
 
14.  The TA will provide 61 person-months of consultancy services—18.5 person-months of 
international (5) and 42.5 person-months of national consultants (7)—through a consulting firm. 
The international input comprises an SOE reform and corporate governance specialist (and 
team leader), corporate restructuring specialist, financial restructuring specialist, SOE legal and 
regulatory expert, social safeguard specialist; the national experts are an SOE reform and 
corporate restructuring specialist, financial specialist, SOE legal and regulatory expert, poverty 
and social development specialist, gender specialist, social safeguard specialist, and translator 
and editor. The consulting firm will be selected by quality- and cost-based selection (QCBS 
80:20)  method  using  the  simplified  technical  proposal.  The  consultants  will  work  on  an 
intermittent  basis  and  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the TA 
consultants is in Appendix 3.  
 
15.  Several workshops will be held intermittently to strengthen the capacity of MOF and the 
line ministries and to discuss, comment, and obtain stakeholder feedback on the evolving 
framework for SOE reform. Workshops will engage national and international resource persons 
as needed. While consultants will support and conduct workshops, seminars, and conferences 
(including logistical arrangements), an advance payment facility will be used as needed by the 
executing agency, which will manage and administer the activity costs, including the liquidation 
of advances.  
 
16.  The consultant team will assist MOF and selected SOEs in undertaking a corporate audit 
of the safeguard policy aspects, and solve labor-related issues and gender concerns arising 
from  the  restructuring  of  selected  SOEs  under  PFR2,  within  the  remit  of  the  relevant 
government regulations. The restructuring of general corporations and institutional capacity 
building envisaged under the MFF are gender neutral; however, due diligence of selected SOEs 
will ascertain human development and human resource aspects and training needs, including 
entry points for incorporating gender design features. There will be special focus on measures 
to promote women’s representation in higher levels of SOE management, training targets for 
women,  and  promotion  of gender  sensitivity  in  the  SOE  workplace.  The gender  specialist 
engaged under the TA will prepare a gender action plan for the selected SOEs. 
 
17.  TA implementation will be closely monitored and evaluated through ongoing consultation 
with stakeholders, regular review missions, and periodic progress reports. The TA will support 
timely distillation and dissemination of recommendations and lessons through print and web-
based publication of working papers and support for stakeholder workshops and conferences. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Strengthening Support for State-Owned Enterprise Reform and 
Corporate Governance Facilitation Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  State-owned  enterprise  reform  and  corporate  governance  specialist,  and team 
leader (5 person-months, intermittent). The international state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform 
specialist and team leader will have a successful track record in corporate restructuring of large 
SOEs and privatization of financial institutions in a number of transitional economies. The expert 
will be responsible for all activities under the technical assistance (TA), ensure timely delivery of 
all outputs, and ensure that the team coordinates with the national counterparts. Previous work 
experience in Viet Nam will be an advantage. More specifically, the specialist will undertake the 
following: 
(i)  Review sector reports, government decisions, and other reports relating to the 
overall  SOE  sector  apart  from  the  sector  reports,  review  the  progress  in 
implementing  periodic  financing  request  (PFR)  1,  and  become  familiar  with 
recently completed studies by consultants engaged under Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  capacity  development  TA,  Central  Institute  for  Economic 
Management and other development partners on SOE reform; and, with the help 
of the legal experts, get acquainted with laws and regulations governing SOEs. 
(ii)  With the help of the other consultants, lead the due diligence assessment of the 
selected SOEs. Taking the restructuring plan as the base, the due diligence 
exercise should include an evaluation of each SOE’s financial health, corporate 
structure and reporting arrangements, management capability, business lines 
and performance trends, governance structure, human resource capacity, and 
operating policies and procedures so as to detect gaps and problems that need 
resolving. Prepare a detailed report on the findings and recommendations for 
each SOE, covering measures to improve corporate governance, operational and 
financial efficiency, internal reporting, and financial disclosure. 
(iii)  With the help of the other consultants, build a financial model using Excel to 
assess the impact of the proposed periodic financing request (PFR) 2, if it were to 
be disbursed, on the borrowing general corporation’s financial position; identify 
key risks and their impact by way of a cash-flow sensitivity analysis at different 
levels of key revenue and expense items.  
(iv)  Prepare  for  each  selected  entity  a  financial  management  assessment  in 
accordance with ADB's Financial Due Diligence: A Methodology Note (January 
2009)  and  ADB's  Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of 
Projects (2005). 
(v)  Ensure that the government adheres to the financial reporting, auditing, and 
disclosure requirements for PFR2. 
(vi)  In  line  with  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  framework  for  the  multitranche 
financing facility (MFF), specify parameters and methodologies for each SOE 
that will help monitor progress and achievements of the project. 
(vii)  In coordination with the national poverty and social sector and gender specialists, 
assess potential social risks associated with the project and prepare mitigation 
plans or other measures. 
(viii)  Help the international social safeguard specialist carry out corporate audits of 
selected SOEs for environmental safeguard measures under ADB Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009). 
(ix)  Hold  workshops  and  meetings  with  various  stakeholders  to  ensure  effective 
policy dialogue, the timely dissemination of information, and consensus-building.

Appendix 3        11 
 
(x)  Monitor and coordinate the schedules and outputs of the team of experts.  
(xi)  Assist the Ministry of Finance (MOF) in preparing the documents for the PFR2. 
 
 
2.  Corporate restructuring specialist (4.5 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will 
have extensive practical  experience of restructuring general corporation. The specialist’s tasks 
will include the following: 
(i)  Become  familiar  with  Viet  Nam’s  corporate  laws  and  regulations,  previous 
decisions relating to SOE reforms, and recent reports on the progress in the 
corporate restructuring of large SOEs (the general corporations) in Viet Nam, and 
identify any constraints to corporate restructuring; in coordination with the team 
leader, conduct a due diligence assessment of the selected general corporations, 
including their legal mandates, corporate arrangements, performance of each 
subsidiary over the past 3 years, board structures, management arrangements, 
and  individual  restructuring  plans  for  the  next  5–7  years  to  determine  the 
financial and technical assistance required for their corporate restructuring, and 
possible  equitization  and  stock  listing;  in  coordination  with  the  team  leader, 
assess and specify the required managerial and technical skills to implement the 
restructuring plan. 
(ii)  Recommend  ways  to  improve  these  documents  and  the  accompanying 
projections that demonstrate the effect of the changes. Guide the management of 
each SOE in incorporating these changes and the strategic direction to pursue. 
(iii)  Suggest areas that could be considered for support under PFR2 of the State-
Owned Enterprise Reform and Corporate Governance Facilitation Program, such 
as improving corporate governance, organization and ownership structure, board 
structure,  management  functions,  divisional  responsibilities,  human  resource 
management policy, and performance reporting and financial disclosure. Assist 
the team leader in defining parameters for monitoring progress and in carrying 
out tasks under his or her terms of reference. 
 
3.  Financial restructuring specialist (4.5 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will 
have broad experience in dealing with financial restructuring issues related to SOE reform and 
privatization. Previous work experience in Viet Nam will be an advantage. The specialist’s main 
tasks will include the following: 
 (i)  Become  familiar  with  Viet  Nam’s  financial  management  laws,  regulations, 
government decisions, and recent progress in the financial restructuring of large 
SOEs. Define obstacles to or constraints on the financial restructuring process.   
(ii)  In coordination with the TA team leader, conduct a due diligence assessment of 
the  selected  SOEs—covering  their  overall  financial  performance  over  the 
previous 3 years, the individual performance of subsidiaries over the same 3 
years, and performance trends of each business over that period—and prepare a 
detailed report on the findings and recommendations for each SOE. 
(iii)  Taking the restructuring plan as the base, review relevance and suitability of the 
approved  financial  restructuring  and  implementation  plans  for  each  SOE. 
Suggest ways to improve these documents and the accompanying projections 
demonstrating the effect of the changes; in the process, assess and specify the 
required managerial and technical skills to implement the restructuring plan.   
(iv)  Suggest areas that could be considered for technical support, such as improving 
financial  planning  and  budgeting,  financial  management  system,  capital 
expenditures  and  debt  management,  risks  management,  divisional 
responsibilities, internal control and auditing arrangements, and internal reporting

12  Appendix 3 
 
and  financial  disclosure.  Assist  the  team  leader  in  defining  parameters  for 
monitoring progress in the financial restructuring process. 
(v)  Assess the level of financial support required by each SOE under PFR2.  
(vi)  Assist the team leader in preparing documents required by MOF for PFR2 and 
carry out any other tasks required by the team leader. 
 
4.   State-owned enterprise legal and regulatory expert (2 person-months, intermittent). 
The consultant will have broad experience in dealing with policy, legal, and regulatory issues 
relating to SOE reforms. Knowledge of Viet Nam’s legal and regulatory system will be an 
advantage.  The  expert  will  undertake  the  following  tasks  in  coordination  with  the  other 
consultants: 
(i)  Review the legal and regulatory impediments to SOE reform, restructuring, and 
the  equitization  and  privatization  process,  and  recommend  measures  to 
accelerate SOE reforms in Viet Nam. 
(ii)  In coordination with the team leader, ensure that the proposed restructuring 
process for the selected SOEs is consistent and in conformity with local legal 
provisions.   
(iii)  In coordination with the team leader, manage legal impediments in the design 
and implementation of PFR2.    
 
5.  Social safeguard specialist (2.5 person-months, intermittent). The consultant will have 
a degree in social science and at least 10 years of experience in involuntary resettlement and 
indigenous peoples safeguards.  Experience working in Southeast Asia and/or Viet Nam is an 
advantage. The main tasks include: 
(i)  Conduct a corporate audit of each selected SOE as to its environmental and 
social management system (under ADB Safeguard Policy Statement). 
(ii)  Assess  each  selected  SOE’s  ability  to  manage  all  relevant  social  and 
environmental risks to and impacts on its business and operations, in particular 
the issues identified in the ADB Safeguard Requirements Handbook 1 to 3.  
(iii)  Review  the  participating  SOEs’  past  and  current  performance  against  the 
objectives, principles, and requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, 
and assess their compliance with the above safeguard policy at the corporate 
level  as  well  as  with  all  local  relevant  laws  and  country's  obligations  under 
international law.  
(iv)  Suggest activities and/or action to improve the existing environmental and social 
management  system,  and  recommend  measures  for  improvement,  and  if 
necessary, help establish the system. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
6.  State-owned enterprise reform and corporate restructuring specialist (12 person-
months, intermittent). The specialist will be familiar with all aspects of SOE reforms in Viet Nam 
and be proficient in English. The specialist will be responsible for providing inputs related to the 
restructuring  approaches  and  help  promote  pertinent  policy  dialogue  among  stakeholders. 
Specifically, the specialist will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Assist the ADB project team and the team leader in all aspects of their work as 
covered by these terms of reference. Under the guidance of the team leader, 
collect  and  analyze  information,  translate  into  English,  and  ensure  that  the 
information is available in a timely manner. Help translate into Vietnamese all 
reports that have to be submitted to the government by the ADB project team 
and the TA team.

Appendix 3        13 
 
(ii)  Conduct research on specific topics as required by ADB and the team leader, 
provide inputs to the restructuring approach, and help promote policy dialogue. 
(iii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and help the team leader 
prepare materials, including the translation of documents and discussions. 
 
7.   Financial specialist (12 person-months, intermittent). The specialist should have a 
background in corporate finance, and knowledge of the SOE sector and of the financial and 
capital markets in Viet Nam. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Assist the international financial and corporate experts in all aspects of their tasks 
within these terms of reference. 
(ii)  Under the guidance of the international experts, collect and analyze information, 
translate into English, and make that information available on a timely basis. 
Help  translate  into  Vietnamese  all  reports  that  have  to  be  submitted  to  the 
government by the ADB project team and the international experts. 
(iii)  Conduct research on specific topics as required by the international financial and 
corporate experts. 
(iv)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and help the ADB project 
team and the international experts prepare materials, including the translation 
of documents and discussions. 
 
8.  State-owned enterprise legal and regulatory expert (6 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert should have a sound background of the legal and regulatory system in Viet Nam, 
particularly of issues related to SOE reforms, and be proficient in English. The expert's tasks 
include the following: 
(i)  Assist the international legal and regulatory expert in all aspects of his or her tasks. 
(ii)  Under the guidance of the international legal and regulatory expert, collect and 
analyze information, translate it into English, and ensure that the information is 
available in a timely manner; and help translate into Vietnamese those reports 
that need to be made available to the government. 
 
9.  Poverty  and  social  development  specialist  (3  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
specialist  should  have  a  sound  background  in  local  labor  laws  and  international  labor 
standards,  in  particular  those  related  to  SOE  reforms,  and  be  proficient  in  English. The 
consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Assist the team leader in ascertaining where the project fits with the national 
poverty reduction strategy (or other national development plans), ADB’s country 
poverty analysis, and ADB’s country partnership strategy. 
(ii)  Identify potential social risks associated with the project and prepare mitigation 
plans or other measures during implementation. 
(iii)  Propose measures to ensure that the project complies with national labor laws 
and  international  core  labor  standards.  Help  the  team  leader  recognize 
opportunities within the project to apply the ADB safeguard policy and mitigate 
the  effects  of  potential  layoffs  of  workers.  Identify  possible  targets  and 
indicators for the project performance management system. 
(iv)  Assist the team leader in resolving labor-related problems and issues, and in 
drafting assurances related to labor issues. 
(v)  Collect  and  analyze  information  and  translate  into  English.  Assist  with 
translation into Vietnamese of reports required by the government under the TA. 
 
10.  Gender specialist (2 person-months, intermittent). The specialist should have a very 
strong background and prior work experience in gender activities in Viet Nam. In due diligence

14  Appendix 3 
 
of  selected  SOEs,  the  specialist  will  assess  and  specify  human  development  and  human 
resource aspects and training needs to cater to the skills requirements of female workers (to 
ensure that female and male workers alike are successfully retrained and redeployed under the 
restructuring efforts). This will include identifying entry points for incorporating gender design 
features in PFR2 and the ensuing documentation, and in the process, preparing a gender action 
plan for the candidate SOEs for PFR2. Specific focus will be on measures to promote women’s 
representation in higher levels of SOE management, training targets for women, and promotion 
of  gender  sensitivity  in  the  SOE  workplace.  The  specialist  will  assist  the  team  leader  in 
establishing  how  the  project  relates  to  priorities  in  the  national  gender  strategy  and 
regulations, and ADB’s gender policy, and how to incorporate gender concerns within the project 
design. 
 
11.   Social safeguard specialist (2.5 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will have a 
degree  in  social  science  and  good  experience  in  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous 
peoples safeguards in Viet Nam. The specialist will support the international social safeguard 
expert  in  all  assigned  tasks,  provide  logistics  support,  and  translate  documents  whenever 
required. 
 
12.  Translator  and  editor  (5  person-months,  intermittent).  A  professional  editor 
experienced in translations from Vietnamese into English and vice versa, will be engaged to 
undertake all tasks associated with an editor, assist in the translation of reports, development of 
publications  and  other  documents,  edit  materials  that  will  be  publicly  disseminated  and 
published in Vietnamese, and also act as an interpreter when required.  
 
C.   Workshops and Seminars 
13.   All consultants will assist and/or participate in a series of workshops and/or seminars 
designed and organized in consultation with the ADB project team and MOF, to disseminate 
results of their work for the benefit of further SOE reforms. Each workshop should clearly define 
the expected outcome and target audience.
